instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message:
No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air.. Its been water damaged. 

Where to start. 

The motherboard starts. I have green light and fan spin. The apple logo on LCD cannot be seen. The screen is black.'
Where to start now?

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: Voltage on backlight output?

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: 2 sec im gonna chekc now

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: Shine a light through the Apple logo do you even get image? Does the board even chime?

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 38084"]Shine a light through the Apple logo do you even get image? Does the board even chime?[/QUOTE]

1. No apple logo when adding light to the screen. The screen is pitch black still.
2. I get chime when pushing start button. And the apple logo on the back of the LCD is lit. But not front.
3. L7701 (I have 8,5 Voltage). On Diode mode I have 0.384.
4. <CAPACITOR>C7710</CAPACITOR> (resistance mode I get 0.428) and Voltage mode 5.12V)

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: so you get backlight but no image since you state the apple logo lights up. try a known good screen check lvds cable for damage. any damage on lvds connector itself?

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Gmorb, post: 38086"]so you get backlight but no image since you state the apple logo lights up. try a known good screen check lvds cable for damage. any damage on lvds connector itself?[/QUOTE]

NO apple logo at all.. The screen is black.. Im following some examples now from step by step: REWA [URL]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-7_paJiwMO8[/URL]

Will reply shortly after my finds.

I have: <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>: pin1: 5.1v - pin2: 0.6v (Should be: Pin1: 8.5v, Pin2: 2.8v) According to REWA.
I have: <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>: pin1: 18.5v - pin2: 00.00v (Should be i guess here same: Pin1: 8.5v, Pin2: 2.8v) ???

On: <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR>: I get 1.7v on both pins. (Should be 3.3v on both pins)

What should I do now, change the resistors or could it be a bad <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>..?

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: measure those resistors first if they are good then check <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> on pin 5 sometimes feedback ball will be missing then you'll know you must replace the led driver and run wires. Either way if i were you id inspect the board and replace or reflow and clean anything that looks badly corroded and damaged before you go measuring. try reflowing led driver as well.

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Gmorb, post: 38088"]measure those resistors first if they are good then check <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> on pin 5 sometimes feedback ball will be missing then you'll know you must replace the led driver and run wires. Either way if i were you id inspect the board and replace or reflow and clean anything that looks badly corroded and damaged before you go measuring. try reflowing led driver as well.[/QUOTE]

Measure the resistors.. Do i need to take them off the board first? Because ive now measured them whilst on the board with voltage..

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: disconnect power from the board and measure them on the board. no need to remove them.

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Gmorb, post: 38090"]disconnect power from the board and measure them on the board. no need to remove them.[/QUOTE]

1. Ok, thanks. Should it be diode mode? Resistance mode correct?
No worries. I found it on ifixit how to do it [URL="https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Use+A+Multimeter/25632#s65006"]https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+...r/25632#s65006[/URL]

2. reflow <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and LED driver.. How much temperature?

Ok. So now ive check the resistors: <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>

<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> Shows 120k (should be in schematic 200k), <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> shows 99.6k (in schematic it says 100K, so that one is ok).

That means <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> needs to be changed?

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message:
no <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> is ok if it was higher than the rated resistance then yes it would be bad. make sure you reflow the led driver until you see it move (dance around) add a good amount of flux. i always have my hot air station at 400 degrees and 80 for air. whatever works for you though.

make sure you check if ball on pin 5 is even there.

make sure you check if ball on pin 5 is even there.[/QUOTE]

Thanks u for helping me out really.. im very greatful.. Love to fix my first board.. Im going to stay on this thread until we have solved this board.. Will be my first.. hope thats ok with you?

Ive checked pin 5, the ball is still there under when lookin in the microscope. but its hard to measure it, since its under the IC.

1. Ok, i start reflow the LED driver first and then we see next step. back in a bit.. Ps. How do I find the LED DRIVER?? :)

<CHIP>U7701</CHIP> is the LED driver.. I found this video of louis: [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xMhu4WyQZAA[/url]

threads.message: make sure <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> is measuring good too and check voltage on both pins of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: check if you get an image or backlight. if you still dont get an image either an apple logo or flashing folder by flashing light onto the apple logo on the back of the screen then check continuity on pin 18/19 of lvds connector and pin 2 of L8304 and check voltages on pin 18/19 of lvds as well.

1. Could it be the bad Diode(<DIODE>D7701</DIODE>) since its measuring 0v..? Its should measure 0v right, since its a diode.. :) Im stupid sometimes..

I can feel we are several step closer though to get it working. Just need to lock down where the issue is. The laptop is coming on perfect. Ive tried with two working lcd screens. So its not the screen themself. Its the motherboard somewhere..

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: What about <CHIP>U8300</CHIP>...? Could that be a problem?

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message:
Ok means the traces are blown between 18/19 and l830 solder a wire from 18/19 to pin 2 of l830 and verify that there is continuity also make sure you are checking voltages while screen is plugged in.

<CHIP>U8300</CHIP> could be bad but since traces are blown its possible reattaching will fix it and let voltage flow again. Make sure you measure l8304 to see if its good.

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message: Lets start over...Do you have 3.3 volts on pin 18/19 of the LCD connector? If so, you should have image meaning if your screen doesn’t have image, try another known good test screen. If you DON’T have 3.3 volts on pin 18/19, check to see if it makes its way to L8304 pin 1. If yes, possibly blown inductor or bad trace from inductor to screen. If NOT getting voltage on pin 1, check if <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> is present at pin 1 of <CHIP>U8300</CHIP>

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air

If yes, possibly blown inductor or bad trace from inductor to screen. If NOT getting voltage on pin 1, check if <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> is present at pin 1 of <CHIP>U8300</CHIP>[/QUOTE]

threads.title: No backlight on LCD - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air
threads.message:
Locate XW7720, between L7701 and <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>; check if is not corroded.
If board is luquid damaged in the backlight area, change <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>...
